meta.title: Analyse an area of computer science
meta.purpose: This standard involves analysing an area of computer science by explaining key aspects, mechanisms, uses and implementations with examples, relevant issues and how they may be addressed, explaining in detail how technical capabilities and limitations relate to people, comparing and contrasting perspectives, and drawing insightful conclusions about the area.

grade_descriptors.N1: Evidence does not reach the minimum threshold for Achieved-level indicators.
grade_descriptors.N2: Some Achieved-level indicators are met, but not enough to satisfy all required Achieved criteria.
grade_descriptors.A3: All Achieved-level indicators are met; no Merit-level indicator meets the Merit threshold.
grade_descriptors.A4: All Achieved indicators are met and at least one Merit indicator is met, but overall performance is below the Merit threshold.
grade_descriptors.M5: All Achieved indicators are met and the Merit threshold is reached; no Excellence-level indicator meets the Excellence threshold.
grade_descriptors.M6: All Achieved indicators are met, all Merit indicators are met, and at least one Excellence indicator is met, but overall performance is below the Excellence threshold.
grade_descriptors.E7: All Achieved and Merit indicators are met and the Excellence threshold is reached, but not all Excellence indicators are met.
grade_descriptors.E8: All Achieved, Merit, and Excellence indicators are met.

key_terms.definition: Extremely large or complex datasets that cannot be processed effectively with traditional tools.
The amount of data generated, often measured in terabytes or more.
The speed at which data is created, collected, and processed.
The different types and formats of data, such as text, images, logs, or sensor data.
The reliability and accuracy of data, including issues like noise, bias, or missing values.
Policies and processes that control how data is collected, stored, used, and protected.
A series of steps for moving data from source to storage to analysis.
Systematic errors in data that can produce unfair or misleading outcomes.
Using many computers together to handle large or complex data tasks.
Principles guiding responsible data use, including privacy, fairness, and accountability.

omis.description: Explains key aspects of the chosen big data area, such as volume, variety, velocity, generation, processing, or interpretation.
omis.detection_hint: The response must clearly explain core characteristics or components of big data, not merely list them. Statements like “big data has lots of information” are insufficient without explanation of the specific aspect. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: the key aspects of the computer science area
characteristics of big data (volume, variety, velocity, etc.)
omis.source_ref: AS PDF explanatory note 2; 2026 topic statement

omis.description: Explains relevant mechanisms, processes, or technologies used to generate, store, process, analyse, or represent big data.
omis.detection_hint: The explanation must describe how at least one mechanism works in the big data context. Naming tools (e.g., Hadoop, SQL) without explaining their function does not meet this indicator. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: relevant algorithms or other mechanisms behind the area
processing and analysing data in different formats
omis.source_ref: AS PDF explanatory note 2; 2026 topic statement

omis.description: Explains how big data is used, implemented, or occurs in real contexts, supported with specific examples.
omis.detection_hint: Look for a description of a big data application paired with a specific example (e.g., traffic modelling, fraud detection). Vague claims like “big data helps companies” without an example do not meet this indicator. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: how the area is used, is implemented, or occurs, giving examples
applied concepts to real-world scenarios
omis.source_ref: AS PDF explanatory note 2; Moderator commentary Merit section

omis.description: Explains key problems or issues in big data such as privacy, bias, data quality, or governance, and how these have been or may be addressed.
omis.detection_hint: A valid response must identify a specific issue (e.g., algorithmic bias) AND describe an addressing method (e.g., diverse training sets). Mentioning an issue alone is insufficient. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: key problems or issues related to the area and how these have been or may be addressed
big data considerations (privacy, ethics, and data governance)
omis.source_ref: AS PDF explanatory note 2; 2026 topic statement

omis.description: Explains how technical capabilities and limitations of big data systems relate to people, users, or stakeholders, with examples.
omis.detection_hint: Look for explicit linkage between system capabilities/limitations (e.g., scalability, latency, accuracy) and human consequences (e.g., decision-making, workload, access). Technical description alone is insufficient. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: how the technical capabilities and limitations of the area relate to humans, giving examples
applied concepts to real-world scenarios
omis.source_ref: AS PDF explanatory note 2; Moderator commentary Merit section

omis.description: Compares and contrasts different perspectives on the big data area, such as ethical, computational, social, organisational, or governance viewpoints.
omis.detection_hint: A comparison must include at least two perspectives AND contrast them using explicit comparative language (e.g., whereas, on the other hand). Listing perspectives separately without comparison is insufficient. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: comparing and contrasting different perspectives
compare two approaches

omis.description: Provides depth and breadth by exploring complex or interconnected aspects of big data using well-chosen examples.
omis.detection_hint: Look for multi-layered explanations, such as linking data formats to processing constraints or connecting bias to governance. A single undeveloped example indicates insufficient depth or breadth. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: analyse, in depth, an area of computer science
adequate depth of analysis with a clear explanation of key concepts
omis.source_ref: AS PDF achievement criteria; Moderator commentary Merit section

omis.description: Draws insightful conclusions about the big data area, demonstrating higher-level thinking beyond restating information.
omis.detection_hint: The conclusion must synthesise or evaluate ideas, not summarise. Look for statements showing implications, significance, or consequences. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: drawing insightful conclusions about the computer science area
show deep, critical analysis
omis.source_ref: AS PDF explanatory note 2; Moderator commentary Excellence section

omis.description: Explores less obvious or longer-term implications of big data, such as systemic bias propagation, future governance challenges, or societal shifts.
omis.detection_hint: Look for impacts that extend beyond immediate technical issues. Simple mentions of privacy or speed are insufficient unless exploring deeper implications. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: broader implications of the topic
complex concepts with significant detail
omis.source_ref: AS PDF explanatory note 4; Moderator commentary (contrast with NA)

omis.description: Justifies predictions about future developments or improvements in big data using clear reasoning linked to current capabilities, limitations, or trends.
omis.detection_hint: The prediction or improvement must include justification grounded in technical or contextual evidence. Unsupported guesses do not meet this indicator. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: making justified predictions
suggesting improvements
